name: Seedy Crisps
headline: Seedy Crisps

image.description:
Seedy Crisps. Alton Brown
Good Eats
EA-1208

Seedy Crisps. Alton Brown
Good Eats
EA-1208

Seedy Crisps. Alton Brown
Good Eats
EA-1208

recipeIngredient: 4 3/4 ounces all-purpose flour, plus additional for rolling

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium bowl whisk together both flours, poppy seeds, sesame seeds, salt, and baking powder. Add the oil and stir until combined. Add the water and stir to combine and create a dough. Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead 4 to 5 times. Divide the dough into 8 equal pieces, cover with a tea towel and allow to rest for 15 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F.

For a thin snacking cracker: On a lightly floured surface, roll out 1 piece of dough to 1/16-inch and place on a parchment lined baking sheet. If there is room on the sheet pan, repeat with a second piece of dough. Bake on the middle rack of the oven for 4 minutes then flip and bake for an additional 2 to 3 minutes or until golden brown. Remove from the oven and place on a cooling rack. When cool, break into desired size pieces. Repeat procedure with remaining dough.
For a thicker dipping cracker: On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough as above but to 1/8-inch thick. Bake for 6 minutes on the first side, then flip and bake another 4 to 6 minutes.

For super even thickness and easy rolling: Roll out using a lightly floured pasta roller. Flatten the dough until it will pass through the first setting and go to the highest number that your pasta roller will allow without tearing the dough. Bake according to the thin cracker instructions.
Note: Baking times will vary depending on exact thickness of dough and oven temperature, so watch them closely. Store in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

review.reviewBody: Has anyone tried making these with only wheat flour? Would they be too brittle or crumbly?

I just made these, last batch is in oven now. They turned out yummy, toasted and crisp. I added 1tbls of each garlic powder and onion flakes as well as 1/8 tsp sesame oil. I used my Atlas pasta machine up to #4 thickness after dividing 8 -81g dough balls. I cut them with my ravioli pasta wheel, giving some sides a decorative ravioli type edge. Next time I may add a bit of tahini. I was looking for a sesame stick recipe but decided on this one to use up the last of our homemade hummus.  Fairly easy recipe, (minus the pasta machine and  burned thumb) lol but it was worth the extra effort for a more uniform cracker.

Very tasty---Keep an eye on them in the oven though. They can brown very quickly once they let off enough steam. No complaints at all. They crisped up nicely and the pasta roller did just the job. Quick and easy to make as well. Will be making these a lot now. (Great with jam for breakfast!) Thanks AB.

I made these crackers pretty much exactly as written, except I subbed hulled sunflower seeds for the poppy seeds and replaced half the sesame seeds with ground pecans (what I had on hand). I let the dough rest in the fridge for a few hours, then rolled each quarter until it almost filled a half sheet pan (very thin) and cut the dough into squares with a pizza cutter before baking. Seven minutes each side in a 400 degree convection oven (it runs very hot). They're delicious and super crunchy. 
There is NOT too much salt in this recipe. I don't get how anyone could think that. I know it's a matter of personal taste, but these are very, very mildly salty.

I don't understand how this recipe got so many high ratings. I made it even though I was skeptical of a cracker recipe with baking powder. Just as I had feared, it's a flat bread recipe without yeast, but leavened with baking powder. It is NOT a cracker recipe. A cracker is supposed to be crisp. This is like soggy bread. Shame on Alton Brown!
As they are, these are good, but try reducing the salt by half, applying a honey wash and sea salt to the rolled dough, cut into cracker shapes, then bake until golden brown.

Excellent recipe. I make it without changes the first time, Then I started modifying. Things to try: sub Chia seeds for sesame. Add 2 tsp Old Bay seasoning. Highly suggested: use a pasta roller. It enables you to roll consistently thin crisps.
This recipe is great . . . other than being too salty.  I will absolutely make it again but with half the salt.

We love these crackers.  Just baked up a batch but have made them many times.  Per other suggestions, I also add 1/2 tsp each of garlic powder and onion powder.  I also substitute 1 Tbsp of olive oil for 1 Tbsp of sesame oil, which I always have on hand.  I agree they need the longer side of the cook times to get crisp.  Yum!
These crackers are wonderful, a huge hit with my husband.  I think they are best baked on the far side of the time, a bit more color and a bit more crisp.  Excellent just as the recipe is written.
I love these crackers.  They don't last long and I live alone.
Rave reviews from guests! Used a sewing pattern tracing wheel to lightly perforate into crackers before baking and could still turn them over as one piece but easy to split into crackers when done.
My brother and I go through 3 lbs of these a week.  It was way worth getting a pasta machine for, plus now we do our own pasta as well.

Delicious! Why did I never think about making crackers before I saw this episode? The instructions here are a bit different from the show (e.g. he played up the pasta roller, and did not flip during cooking).

I did use my pasta roller, for the first time in fact, and it worked great, once I figured out that I needed to roll the ball out a bit before running it through (just flattening in my hand was not enough). I got to 3 on my kitchen aide - the seeds wouldn't run through on 4. I substituted flax for poppy, and they are great. I can't wait to try other variations!

I love AB's tv shows and his cook book.
Has anyone used this recipe in a dehydrator? When I make these I will replace the Flax seeds with Chai seeds.

Any comments?

I love the original recipe and made some variations too.
First batch were made per directions. In the 2nd I omitted the poppy and added onion, garlic, paprika and red pepper powder and parsley - wow, cajun crackers for sure. In the 3rd batch omitted the poppy and added freshly grated Parmesean cheese - yum cheezy crackers. Since my kids are military and away from home, these are a great alternative to cookies in the goodie boxes. They dont turn to crumbs when I put them in a vacuum sealed bag, which is a bonus when shipping over seas. Thanks Alton for a great snack.

This is the 2nd time making these. This time around I used King Arthur Harvest Grains instead of the poppy and sesame seeds, I had to pulse it a few times in my blender since it had some bigger seeds in (pumpkin maybe). I used white whole wheat instead of reg. whole wheat. In the prep. part, after letting the 8 portions rest, I took each one and pressed between parchment with my tortilla press, then put each through my pasta machine (atlas) through to #4. The pressing first with the tortilla maker made the dough perfect for the pasta machine and made the whole thing easy. The 2nd batch I forgot in the oven and went outside, must have been gone almost 10 min. so I didn't turn them and they came out better than the first batch. Nicely brown around the edges. Have to remember that next time!

Whip up a batch of these yummy little crackers of course. I made them almost according to the recipe; I didn't have any sesame seeds so I substituted onion seed instead. (I also used white poppy seeds since that was what I had on hand.)

I rolled it out really thin and they were wonderful. I got distracted during my last batch though and I ended up with a few black crackers I had to throw away. My oven runs hot so I only had them in there for about 9 mins total (at 400) and even then I was cutting it close because I wanted a crispy cracker.

Next time I think I'll probably add a bit of salt on top. The dough tasted salty before it was cooked but after it seemed to need a little more salt. I'll probably experiment with different spices as well since this seems to be a wonderful base for any flavour of cracker.

I always check to see if there's an Alton Brown recipe or technique first when cooking because most of the time his recipes give me a great starting point.

I have made these a few times now. the first time i made them exactly as the recipe says to. the second and third time i added onion and garlic flakes to it and also toasted the seeds before i added them to the dough. Man, what an improvement. i like to experiment with things so i might try some caraway seeds this time.

I made this recipe as a beginner, and it was simple, quick, and easy. Great taste, and great for dipping. I personally made a butter/garlic sauce of my own creation, but I'm sure any range of sauces would work. Great taste. The only downside is that poppy seeds can be expensive!

I thought they were a bit bland, but used it as a starting point, as I was looking for just a sesame cracker. I omitted the poppy seed, and replaced with 1/3 c sesame seeds I toasted in a dry pan. I also added 1/2 t. onion powder and 1/4 t. garlic powder. I also substituted 1/3 of the olive with toasted Asian sesame oil. I was going for that deep sesame flavor. I think next time I might put a light egg wash on the top before baking to shine them up a little. Has anyone tried it with a light coat of egg wash? I had no trouble with just a rolling pin, but I wish someone would buy me the pasta attachment for my kitchen aide mixer. I have wanted one for years, but it is a bit expensive and a frivolous item.
Thanks Alton, your cool!

This was my first time making my own crackers and what a positive way to start. If you can make cookies, you can make crackers! I agree thinner is better. I went to 4 on my Atlas pasta machine. I also salted the tops with fine sea salt before baking. I didn't have quite enough poppy seeds so I used nigella seeds to make up the difference. They added a nice onion-y flavor. As to the aluminum free baking powder. Rumford (red can with a black stripe and white lettering; made by the Clabber Girl Corporation out of Indiana) is a brand that is available here in New England. I will make these again. Cracker on!
I am a kid and  love Alton's Shows and recipes.  I made this one and I love it!  It has the perfect amount of seeds in it . I sent it to my neighbor who is a chef an he loved it.  Thanks Alton!

This recipe has become one of my staples. I have been making these for friends and they are a big hit. I use only sesame seeds rather than a mix of sesame and poppy and they are fantastic. The extra oil in the sesame seeds adds something to the texture of the crackers.

I also add rosemary and garlic powder instead of the seeds to make a great herby cracker for goat cheese.

I didn't have any sesame seeds, but I didn't miss them at all--I added some sunflower seeds, lightly ground, which gave the crackers some nutty flavor. I also added a generous amount of onion powder, a little less garlic powder, a pinch of white pepper, and just a little bit of honey. I used mostly wheat flour. Before baking, I scored lines into the dough and poked holes into the squares with a fork before sprinkling salt on top (most of it won't stick, but in my opinion it does make it taste better). My mom was eating these practically right off of the baking sheet, and I was too!

Since I mill my flour from the grain, I used Soft White Wheat, which is typically used for baking pastry. I used all of the ingredients asked for the first time around. I also used my hand cranked pasta maker. The crackers were very good. I shared them with my networking group the very next morning. Everyone thought they were delicious. I'm going to make them again, since this is the best alternative to buying organic wheat crackers. I can always keep these in the freezer and use them when I want crackers. I don't think I would need quite as much sesame seeds the next time around. I like the suggestion for pumpkin seeds and milled flax seeds.
I can see this recipe as a good base for other flavors of herbs, seeds and spices. Thanks AB.

Made my third batch of these this morning, and again they turned out great!  As with most of AB's stuff, I used this recipe as a starting-off point for something I was completely unfamiliar with.  While you get a great (if not overwhelming) nutty sesame flavor from the original recipe, I like to add white pepper, onion powder & honey to up the flavor.  I even tend to cook them a little over the recommended time to get a nice, brown cracker.  Great with hummus, mild cheeses, and for just plain snacking!

was easy to put together, even easy to roll out, dispite what AB said on his show. i rolled it out to 1/8 of an ince, came out pretty thick, almost cakey even, but still delicious. was even better when i rolled it out to 1/16 of an inch.

my only problem was the baking powder. for the life of me, i checked out everywhere around here, no one has seen nor heard of aluminum free baking powder. i used regular baking powder and i noticed no distinct bitterness. just go with the regular baking powder and it will be fine.

The first time I made this cracker, it came out delicious.  The first ball  of dought that I rolled was a little thicker than the second ball of dough.  The thinner the cracker the better.  I made this using Rye flour and all purpose flour.  The 2nd time I made the cracker, I doubled the sesame seeds and omitted the poppy seeds.  It gave them a nuttier taste.  I found, buying the sesame seeds in larger bags at a local Chinese Market was cheaper than the traditional grocery store.  I agree with some of the other reviews, use a little less salt.

The first time I made these, I made them as directed.  They were delicious if a little salty for my taste.  The second time, I made a few substitutions per my taste that I recommend if you like a nuttier cracker.  I substituted half the poppy seeds with pumpkin seeds, toasted all of the seeds before making the dough, and reduced the salt to a light tsp instead of 1 1/2 tsp.  I also, and this is my favorite sub, replaced 1 tablespoon of Olive Oil with 3 tablespoons of milled flax seed.  This can only be done with milled flax and not with whole flax.  I then finished with a couple of dashes of black pepper (at the request of my 8 and 5 year olds who were helping me make these.)  They came out AMAZINGLY well.  And fun for the family.  The extra milled flax plus a non-stick pizza pan made it so that I didn't even need parchment or non-stick spray.  Delicious, delicious, delicious!

I first did these as listed with the poppy seeds and sesame seeds.  It was real good.  Than I did it omitting the seeds and adding fresh Rosemary.  They were fabulous are better than store bought Rosemary crackers any day.  Only caution is to watch the amount of water you use.

These crackers were a fun thing to do on a cold winter day.  I have a little plastic 'diet' scale, so that came in useful.  But I made them at someone's house using the theory that there are 8 oz. in a cup, and estimating, and they still came out very good.  I rolled out the dough on a floured board with no trouble.  As for taste - perhaps toasting the sesame seeds first would give more flavor, that's what I did.   And one batch  I baked turned a darker tan than the others, giving it a really toasty taste.  Thank you, Alton Brown, I have a new favorite low-fat munchie!

Luckily I did have a small food scale, so I could get close to the measurments of flour. I am a home bread baker so I was not to worried, and these came out perfectly following the directions. I do have a manual pasta machine so that is how I rolled them out. Some I got a bit to brown, but still good. They are not loaded with flavor but I like that as they will go great with any thing that I choose to either dip them in or layer on top. AB for many home cooks using standard measures such as 1 cup instead of ounces of something would make it easier. What many don't understand is that flour is different each day as far as the moisture it absorbs, so that might have been some of their problems. I suspect the person saying to much salt accidentally used TBSP instead of tsp.
I did go online and find a recipe to make the non aluminum baking powder as that was not available to me.

I had too moist of dough as I don't have a way to get ounces of flour. However, I added more flour and was able to put dough through my pasta machine. I ran out of poppy seeds so used a mix of poppy, caraway and dill. Also, I was able to get white sesame seeds which are small. My husband said they are better than store bought. Because the dough fell apart soo much the cracker was a little thicker so I baked them longer so they would be crisp.
Very tasty.

I made these almost exactly as written, subbing only whole wheat pastry flour for regular whole wheat.

The dough came together quickly and was easy to work with. I used the kitchenaid pasta rollers which worked just as well as on the show. Manual pasta rollers would work just as well. As I said it's an easy dough to work with so rolling it out by hand wouldn't be difficult, but I think you'd end up with a more rustic uneven cracker. I rerolled some of the dough several times and there was no noticeable change in the finished product--a big plus.

I cut some of them into shapes for my kids which they liked, but is generally more trouble than it's worth. I preferred baking long strips and breaking them up after baking. This also makes flipping them over much easier than flipping each individual cracker.

It's funny that reviewers have complained about both too much and too little salt--I thought it was perfect! My three-year-old absolutely loves them, too.
Made these for my wife's staff party and they were a hit.  The kids helped mix and roll them out.  Couldn't have been easier.  Substituted flax seeds for poppy seeds.  Added some flavor to the mix.

I am not much of a baker and had some hints from my wife. Based on her suggestions, I lowered the whole-wheat flour to 2 1/4 ounces and increased the all-purpose flour to 7 1/2 ounces. Fortunately, our poppy seeds were stale. So, I used 1/8 cup 5-seed blend (sesame, poppy, caraway, fennel and flax) and 1/4 cup sesame instead of 1/3 cup. The crackers turned out great if you like stronger flavors!

However, next batch will have slightly less 5-seed mix and probably some onion and garlic powders which should really up their flavor.

The nice thing is that this recipe is a little messy to make, but really easy! Thanks, Alton!

There is WAY to much salt in this recipes, a heck lot of too much. Lack of flavor from the seed is blatant, perhaps hidden by the indecent amount of salt.
Coming from the metric system school, I must have gotten mixed up in the ounces by weight and/or by volume, because I first ended up with a way too humid dough, I had to add couple of tablespoon more flour to have something workable.

Otherwhise the texture of the crackers is great, I think I'll do it again by reducing salt to 1/4 teaspoon and perhaps throw some romarin and thyme to give more depth to the flavor.

Thanks anyway Alton !

JF

When I made these, I had trouble with them burning.  I had to use a round baking stone and rotate them every minute or so.  I didn't need to bake them nearly as long as the recipe said.  I almost wonder if it's an altitude thing.  I'm at a lot higher of an elevation than AB.  Needless to say, I was pretty mush tied to the kitchen while I made these.  Flavor and texture wise, however, they were really good.  Also, instead of breaking them after baking, I cut them into squares first.  I thought  they looked more like a cracker that way.  But if you're looking for good homemade crackers, these are good if you're willing to take the time and effort.  I think they're worth a try.

I approached this recipe with the thought that I would make homemade crackers and serve  them with various fine cheeses, Iberico ham and other artisan meats.  I made the crackers in three batches, each of varying thickness, all hand-rolled with a rolling pin.  I was seeking to produce a thicker, more rustic-type cracker and wanted to experiment on the proper thickness.  That being said, the thinnest I could make it with the rolling pin was the proper consistency.  I consider this recipe a good base, as the cracker form was very much what I had hoped.  From a flavor standpoint, there simply wasn't any.  For my personal taste, I believe it requires more salt; perhaps, an additional teaspoonful or two of kosher salt and also additional olive oil.  The cracker would also benefit from the addition of other flavor elements.  Notwithstanding, I'm not disappointed having tried the recipe, as it will form a base for me to experiment with the additions of those other elements.  If your desire is to have a hearty, yet flavorful cracker, you may find yourself disappointed on the flavor.
